rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:1–17:18
rsbNotes.text: 16:1–17:18 Jeremiah is prohibited from marrying and taking part in other normal activities as a sign of coming judgment (ch. 16). A sharp contrast is drawn between the destinies of those who trust in man and in God (17:1–18).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:16
rsbNotes.text:
16:16 fishers . . . hunters. Judah is pictured as the prey of the Lord.

every mountain and every hill . . . clefts of the rocks. There will be no escape (23:24; Is. 2:19).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:17
rsbNotes.text: 16:17 my eyes are on all. See “God Sees and Knows: Divine Omniscience” at Prov. 15:3.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 16:21
rsbNotes.text: 16:21 know that my name is the Lord. Knowing the Lord’s name here means recognizing His authority and power through His acts of judgment.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:1
rsbNotes.text:
17:1 on the tablet of their heart. This metaphor recalls tablets for writing laws. See 31:33, where the law will be written on the heart, and Prov. 3:3; 7:3. In the new covenant, Christ writes the law on His people’s hearts by His Spirit (2 Cor. 3:3).

on the horns of their altars. These altars should commemorate atonement for sin, but where the sin is unforgiven they continue to remind God of the sin itself.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:2
rsbNotes.text: 17:2 their altars and their Asherim. See 2:20 note; Ex. 34:13; Deut. 7:5.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:3
rsbNotes.text: 17:3 the mountains. Mount Zion, where the temple was, was plundered by Nebuchadnezzar (52:17–23).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:4
rsbNotes.text: 17:4 heritage that I gave to you. The Promised Land (2:7).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:7
rsbNotes.text: 17:7 trusts. The Lord repays trust because He is by nature trustworthy (Is. 7:9). The close similarity between vv. 7, 8 and Ps. 1:1–3 suggests that trust in the Lord entails obedience to His law.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:8
rsbNotes.text: 17:8 a tree planted by water. This image is a potent symbol of strength in a dry country (Is. 44:4).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:9
rsbNotes.text: 17:9 The heart. In the Old Testament, the “heart” is more than the seat of emotion. It represents the basis of character, including the mind and the will (4:19; Prov. 4:23; 16:23). See theological note “The Freedom and Bondage of the Will” on next page.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:10
rsbNotes.text: 17:10 mind. Lit. “kidneys.” In ancient Hebrew idiom, these organs represented the seat of the emotions.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:11
rsbNotes.text:
17:11 Like the partridge . . . by justice. It was commonly believed that partridges would steal the eggs of other birds, but the hatchlings would return to their natural parent. In the same way a person will not be able to retain riches unjustly gained.

and at his end . . . fool. On the transience of riches, see Prov. 23:4, 5.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:12
rsbNotes.text:
17:12 A glorious throne. See note 14:21; Ps. 99:1.

from the beginning. This implies that Zion was chosen as God’s throne even before the temple was built (Ex. 15:17).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:13
rsbNotes.text: 17:13 written in the earth. They will soon be forgotten. Contrast the thought of Ex. 32:32.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:15
rsbNotes.text: 17:15 Where is the word of the Lord. With this taunt Jeremiah is accused of being a false prophet (Deut. 18:21, 22). See Mic. 7:10; 2 Pet. 3:2–4.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:18
rsbNotes.text: 17:18 dismayed . . . dismayed. Prayer for judgment upon his enemies is common in Jeremiah (11:20; 12:3; 15:15). The words are reminiscent of his call (1:17).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:20
rsbNotes.text: 17:20 who enter by these gates. The message is given at the gates because of their role in commerce (see Neh. 13:15, 19).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:22
rsbNotes.text: 17:22 keep the Sabbath day holy. Specific appeal is made to the Sabbath commandment (Ex. 20:8–11; Deut. 5:12–15; Neh. 10:31; Is. 56:2).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 17:25–26
rsbNotes.text: 17:25, 26 This prophecy presents a picture (partly repeated in 22:4) of the restoration of the Davidic dynasty, the social structure, and the worship, that all centered on the temple. See also 23:5, 6; 30:9; 33:14–26. All that is threatened for Judah, therefore, can be reversed.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18–20
rsbNotes.text: 18:1–20:18 Just as a potter remolds a marred pot, God will remold His people by disciplining them in exile (18:1–17). Jeremiah portrays God’s judgment by breaking a clay jar (ch. 19), and is mistreated because of his unpopular message (18:18–23; ch. 20).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:2
rsbNotes.text: 18:2 the potter’s house. Apparently in the Valley of the Son of Hinnom, near the Potsherd Gate (19:2); hence the command to “go down.” See also 7:31.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:4
rsbNotes.text: 18:4 reworked it into another vessel. The potter has freedom with respect to his plans. The spoiling of his first intention is not final.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:6
rsbNotes.text: 18:6 O house of Israel. The analogy with Israel follows. The use of the term “Israel” recalls God’s historic purposes of election for the whole people, to which Judah was now heir.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:7–8
rsbNotes.text: 18:7, 8 The potter illustration (vv. 2–4) shows that the Lord’s purposed judgment may be revoked by that nation’s repentance.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:13
rsbNotes.text: 18:13 very horrible thing. One of the strong terms used for idolatry (v. 15; cf. 5:30).

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:14
rsbNotes.text: 18:14 Do the mountain waters. As it would be against nature to turn from cold, running water to polluted, standing water, so it is hard to understand why anyone would turn from God to idolatry.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:15
rsbNotes.text:
18:15 make offerings. See note 11:13.

ancient roads . . . side roads, not the highway. See note 6:16. The “side roads” are narrow, insufficient and dangerous.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:17
rsbNotes.text:
18:17 east wind. Cf. 4:11.

my back, not my face. The meaning is withheld favor (2:27). He will turn His back on them.

rsbNotes.title: Jer 18:20
rsbNotes.text:
18:20 Should good be repaid with evil. Cf. Ps. 35:12; 1 Pet. 2:19–24.

dug a pit. They had murderous intention (v. 22). See Jeremiah’s actual experiences in 37:16; 38:6.

stood before you . . . for them. See note 15:1.
